awd_titl_txt: Management and Operations of the Arecibo Observatory (AO)
awd_abstract_narration:
SRI International (SRI) teams with the Universities Space Research Association (USRA) and Universidad Metropolitana (UMET) to form the Arecibo Management Team (AMT) to manage and operate the Arecibo Observatory (AO). AMT will operate on-site at AO as a unified organization reporting to the AO Director. USRA brings expertise in astronomy and planetary science, while UMET brings expertise in education, public outreach, and facilities management. UMET's large employee base and extensive on-island resources will provide career paths and employment opportunities for new and existing AO staff. 

Twenty-seven supporting institutions will collaborate with AMT to advance a common vision of AO's future in science and education. In addition to these academic institutions, AMT will partner with the Puerto Rico Department of Education and two Puerto Rican economic development agencies. Through its facility development plan, AMT will provide broad technical, equipment, and logistic resources to AO's science and education missions. This includes expanding the AO user base and creating staffing resources and professional development opportunities for AO staff. 

AMT's plan for radio astronomy will focus on science endorsed by the Decadal Survey process: gravitational-wave astronomy through pulsar timing, studies of cosmic structure formation and galactic energetics through neutral-hydrogen surveys and molecular-line spectroscopy, and probes of star formation and collapse through Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI). The planetary radar plan provides invaluable characterization of near-Earth object orbits and physical properties, for mitigation of both potential impact hazards and risks to future robotic and crewed missions. The planetary radar program will also map planets and satellites to uncover surface features, sub-surface geologies, and interior structures. AMT's space and atmospheric sciences (SAS) plan will integrate the NSF Coupling, Energetics, and Dynamics of Atmospheric Regions (CEDAR), National Space Weather, and Climate Change communities as primary stakeholders, and exploit important new programs in ionospheric interactions and conjugate studies. The plans for SAS development include improved 430 MHz transmitter reliability via installation of a solid-state modulator, installation of a magnetic conjugate Incoherent Scatter Radar (ISR), instrument automation and remote control, new helium and metal resonant lidars, a new infrared camera in the optics lab, and a phased-array radar surrounding the AO telescope. 

The management plan weaves AO into the fabric of scientific, educational, and economic development in Puerto Rico. The educational plan will reinstitute a program to bring 42,000 K-12 students to AO for tours and workshops emphasizing STEM education, create a summer research academy for high-school students, train 20 STEM high-school teachers each year, maintain the existing Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program, create undergraduate intern positions in all aspects of AO operations, and create PhD opportunities for Hispanic students with mainland universities. The outreach plan will update the Angel Ramos Foundation Visitor Center to expand the visitor experience with tours of the entire site. Virtual tours of AO and our universe will be developed on an interactive video gaming platform for distribution world-wide. AMT will enhance technical literacy for economic development in Puerto Rico and to train a new generation of astronomers and space scientists from a traditionally underrepresented Hispanic population.

PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT
ARECIBO OBSERVATORY

OCT 2011 - MARCH 2018

From 2011 to 2018, SRI International (SRI) operated the National Science Foundation (NSF) Arecibo Observatory (AO) in Puerto Rico with support from Universidad Metropolitana (UMET) and the Universities Space Research Association (USRA) under a Cooperative Support Agreement.

The Arecibo Management Team (AMT) exploited its superior capabilities in radio astronomy, planetary science, and space and atmospheric science as well as administrative expertise and support available at each of the AMT home institutions. This successful model was also adopted by the team that took over the Observatory after SRI elected not to pursue a follow-on contract.

The balance of AO staffing improved significantly under AMT management: 85% of the AO workforce is Hispanic, and 22% are women. At least three scientific staff members are persons with disabilities.

Arecibo is still the best (and in practice the only) instrument available for the most sensitive needs (e.g., in the cores of globular clusters, where the density of stars makes the probability of gravitational interactions much higher than it would be in the galactic plane). It creates an ideal environment to observe the formation and disruption of binaries, the spin-up of pulsars through accretion processes, and the formation of exotic systems through repeated exchange encounters.

The planetary science program at Arecibo Observatory concentrates on NASA-funded radar observations of potentially hazardous near-Earth objects (NEOs) such as comets, asteroids, spacecraft mission candidates, and the terrestrial planets.

Approximately 450,000 visitors were exposed to science and technology at the Angel Ramos Foundation Science and Visitor Center (SVC) between 2011 and 2018, with annual numbers increasing by about 18,000 a year. Students made up 23% of all visitors (K-16+). The Center completed a major externally funded renovation that included updated science exhibits, received a Certificate of Excellence from TripAdvisor, became affiliated with the Smithsonian, increased media interest and coverage, and developed strong partnerships with public and private sectors across the island.

AO maintains a schedule of workshops, symposia, observation nights, and general outreach activities as well as a Space Academy, funded through a NASA SSERVI (Solar System Exploration and Research Virtual Institute) subcontract, and vibrant REU and RET (Research Experiences for Undergraduates/Teachers) Programs.

The AO William E. Gordon telescope is fully committed except for scheduled maintenance periods and the impacts of unusual events. All available time is allocated to radio astronomy, planetary radar, and atmospheric and space science. Pulsar radio astronomy accounts for most telescope time, followed by ISR/SAS, non-pulsar radio astronomy, and planetary radar. VLBI and the Search for Extraterrestrial Intelligence (SETI) Institute account for the remaining time.

AO continues to expand its capabilities to support scientific users including an upgraded lidar laboratory, the Arecibo Observatory Remote Optical Facility (AO-ROF), located on the island of Culebra approximately 95 miles east of Arecibo, and a new ionospheric heating facility that became operational during this reporting period.

On 13 January 2014, a 6.4 magnitude earthquake damaged a main platform suspension cable. Telescope motion and most maintenance activities were immediately halted and the VC was closed to the public as a precaution until the damage and risks could be assessed by outside specialists. AO staff then moved expeditiously to acquire the materials and perform the structural work necessary to complete the repair. The Gordon telescope returned to full service on 11 March 2014.

The Arecibo telescope was also shut down for 8 weeks in 2016 for large-scale maintenance activities postponed in past years. Although a shutdown of this scale had never been performed before at Arecibo, it was successful and will be considered as an option for future program plans

AO maintains a comprehensive hurricane preparedness plan. In 2017, Hurricane Maria created unimaginable destruction and chaos in Puerto Rico. The observatory lost commercial power and relied on the use of its generators to power the site and maintain basic operational capability. Communications were hampered significantly; landlines, cell phones, and Internet lines were interrupted for weeks. Only satellite phones provided communications, but basic observatory operational capability was restored within 7 days after hurricane Maria hit the island. AO?s support of the local community was an important part of recovery. The Observatory received FEMA, National Guard, and Coast Guard supplies, delivered via at least 10 helicopter flights, for distribution to neighboring communities. The AO also provided radio communication repeater services to the Puerto Rico power authority and local police.
